text: poets as far as I'm concerned can do
whatever they want as long as they do it
well and then put it out there and let
people find it maybe three people find
it maybe 3,000 people find it maybe 3
million people find it but you know the
poet's job to my mind the artist's job
is to be true to his or her sense of of
voice and then whatever rules are
established for the poem itself to to
execute those rules at the highest level
you know that's how you measure the
success or the accomplishment of a poem
so you know Wallace Stevens you know the
first lines of Sunday morning
complacencies of the
penir well you
know but it's an amazing phrase
complacent encies of the penir right I
mean you can you say it over and over
again and it kind of morphs and changes
and makes you ask and think and wonder
and the word penir is a fabulous word
and you know poetry can sort of wash
over you and be a very visceral
experience even if um it is abstract in
the sense of you know not conveying
straightforward and immediately
identifiable meaning poems are not the
newspaper
you know so while sometimes poems impart
absolutely clear information that is not
their charge and um so what I would like
to see is a an increased tolerance and
curiosity of the different kinds of uh
of ways of being excellent in different
sorts of
language
